dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi careens down narrow roadways at breakneck speeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back seat is WHITTLESLEY. Early 40's, the wreck of handsome man. Unshaven.  Sweat stained.  Rail thin.  Scra arms, a fresh scar on one cheek.  As the taxi roars downh the harbor, Whittlesley leans over the front seat.  (Ital Portuguese to be subtitled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faster! We won't make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whittlesley pulls out A KNIFE, puts it to the driver's ju

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweat pouring down his brow, the driver re-doubles his sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi swerves around a corner, nearly crashing into a flies out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light rain obscures the bulky outlines of tethered freigh faint laughter leavened with Portuguese phrases, distant from waterfront bars.  One of the smaller boats, the SANT loading as the TAXI fishtails to a halt. Whittlesley gets out, sees the boat still at dock.  His f with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses a handful of bills into the driver's lap, sprin pier as the driver shouts curses after him in Portuguese. shoves past the dock hands as the last load goes onto the The boat's engines churn to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to speak to the captain! Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sailors hold Whittlesley back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me! I'm trying to save your lives, you fools!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several crew members murmur the word "loco".  Hearing the squat man wearing a billed hat and smoking a cigar approa FRANCO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: American?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Thank Christ somebody speaks English.  I'm Dr. John Whittlesley. You have some crates of mine on board.  They were shipped by mistake to the Natural History Museum.  We have to get them off the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have I.D.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whittlesley runs a trembling hand through his hair, tryin control and appear reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Let me explain.  I was on an expedition for the museum on the Upper Xingu.  Something horrible happened.  I'm the only one who got out alive.  I lost everything, my I.D., everything.  I have to make sure no one else dies.  The crates, the crates were sent out before we knew.  There's something unspeakable inside.  If your boat leaves harbor with those crates on board, I can't be responsible.  My God, if they reach New York...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whittlesley's fists clench spasmodically.  Franco looks t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  I'm not crazy!  As God is my witness, I'm telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franco barks an order and several sailors grab Whittlesle arms.  They start to lead him back to shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do this! You have to believe me. Your lives are in danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sailors laugh.  But with an almost super-human streng desperation, Whittlesley throws them off.  He pulls out h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash.  Cash, you see?  American money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whittlesley throws the money down on the deck.  The breez bills across the bow and all the men, including Captain F scramble for the money, chattering in Portuguese.  While occupied, Whittlesley slips by unnoticed and disappears b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whittlesley ducks between cages of goats, boxes of farm e movements jerky with panic.  As he continues searching, t moves past him, into the darkness of the hold.  We hear W mumbling between low, ragged breaths.  At the back of the camera finds...  A STACK OF CRATES... clearly labeled NATURAL HISTORY MUSE these as... The CRATES VIBRATE.  The boat has started to Whittlesley stands bolt upright, realizing what's going o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late.  He turns to run back on deck but then stops, s A look of desperation fills his eyes.  With one hand he p KNIFE, and unexpectedly puts it to HIS OWN NECK.  Better himself than face what comes next.  The knife touches...  A NECKLACE of TWO ARROWS, one gold, another silver. Whittlesley stares wide-eyed into the blackness of the ho start BLEATING in blind panic.  A shaft of moonlight come porthole as the boat turns.  The moonlight falls on THE CRATES.  Whittlesley's eyes lock onto them and he inc them, drawn inexorably closer... closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins mumbling a prayer. MOVE IN ON HIS EYES... filled with dread as he falls to h staring, always staring at THE CRATES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew tends to business and the Santa Lucia points out harbor, disappears into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squad cars roar down the back roads, sirens flashing.  In the column is an unmarked car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the wheel is a strikingly dignified and imposing black a simple, old-fashioned dark suit, narrow black tie, and This is SPECIAL AGENT PENDERGAST, FBI. A BACH SONATA for violin and harpsichord plays on the tap Pendergast hums along as he drives.  A SMALL TOWN COP rid The cop is intimidated both by Pendergast and the morning sweats heavily as he brings Pendergast up to date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the locals found it at dawn. Didn't believe him 'till I saw it myself.  Even then I didn't believe it.  Scared my men shitless.  Me too. I mean... hell... You could smell it a half mile away, Mr. Pendergast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unperturbed) Any of your men go on board?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.  No way.  None of us wanted to, I'm the first to admit it.  I said, "Don't get within a mile of this thing.  It's way to big for us. I'm calling the FBI."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast nods his approval, resumes humming along with particularly intricate harpsichord riff.  As always, the unflappable and totally calm as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ocean is still, the air stifling and close.  A hot su on the deck of the SANTA LUCIA.  The boat lists at a craz it has been washed up on the shore.  At first glance, it deserted.  A barrel rolls back and forth as the boat is r successive wave.  We hear sirens approaching and the phal cars pulls up.  Joining them now are TWO AMBULANCES. PENDERGAST gets out along with the others.  All of the co cover their faces, gagging violently at the smell.  Pende once and frowns.  Apart from this, he doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choking) Goin' up-wind if you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast nods.  The cops all fall back in revulsion.  T a safe distance as Pendergast approaches the ghost ship. laced wing-tips sink in the sand.  He leans down, pulls t a time.  He balls both socks, puts them carefully into hi proceeds barefoot towards the boat. Using a piece of driftwood as a plank, Pendergast leans i Santa Lucia.  With surprising agility, he leaps up the pl deck.  At the top he touches a rail.  It's covered in a D LIQUID. BLOOD.  Flies buzz loudly.  A LARGE MACHETE lies abandone Chairs are overturned.  A DEAD GOAT, eviscerated, lies in lifeboat hangs half off the stern.  Pendergast moves aft. watch from the sand below, unwilling to get any closer. hears A DOOR slamming open and closed.  He follows the no sees...  THE DOOR TO THE HOLD.  He approaches, pushes it open and stairwell.  Below deck are BODIES... stacks of them.  They've been TORN TO SHREDS. THE CAMERA MOVES down to one particular man who is neares the stairs.  It's CAPTAIN FRANCO.  His face is frozen in terror.  Flies congregate in the eye sockets.  With his f nudges the body over.  The skull has been torn open. THERE IS NO BACK TO FRANCO'S HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: Silence then we begin hearing sounds of the city... horns construction work. SUPER TITLE... NEW YORK CITY, FOUR MONTHS LATER as we...

dialogues.text: ON A NECKLACE of TWO ARROWS, one of gold, the other silve to the one seen on Whittlesley.  Widen to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the woman wearing the necklace... MARGO GREEN.  She s coffee as she makes notes on several large FOSSILIZED TEE is neatly combed.  No make-up.  She doesn't need it.  She unselfconscious beauty and a mind like a steel trap. At Margo's elbow is a small T.V.  A CNN world news report Margo's New York Times is open to the crossword puzzle, w been doing rapidly, in ink.  Clearly this is a woman who with a mind that can handle more than one thing at a time An alarm on her watch beeps and she fills in the last two crossword puzzle, makes one final note on the fossil spec shuts off the T.V.  She reaches for her back pack and loo CENTRAL PARK with remarkably clear eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELICOPTER SHOT... Swooping over the fall foliage of the of color and botanical life... The camera picks out MARGO making its way along the winding roads, dodging taxi cabs jeans, a work shirt, a fine blue gabardine jacket with a DOUBLE HELIX PIN.  On her back is a LEATHER BACK PACK whi lap top computer.  She emerges from the park, catches the and rolls up to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Margo arrives, the camera moves up and over the buildi rest on the imposing turrets, intersecting roof lines, an arches of the MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY.  This is not an building; it's a 19th century monument to science and man structure fills an entire city block. Happy visitors pour into the museum as Margo takes the im stone steps two at a time.  We hear SCREAMS of pleasure a the normal raucous noises of a large group of THIRD GRADE Margo is amused to find herself surrounded by kids.  Thei MRS. BEASLEY, a stern woman in glasses with a thick New Y calls after them as they all head inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't run, children!  Stay with your partner and do not run!  If anyone runs they will be sent back to the bus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignoring Mrs. Beasley, TWO BOYS charge past Margo.  HENRY Henry has a buzz cut; Larry has rasta dread knots.  Both old, wear high top sneakers and shorts so big they graze

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry!  Larry!  What did I just say! You walk right this minute!  Did you hear me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly, Henry and Larry slow to a rapid race-walk as the huge doorway flanked by two Northwest Coast Indian to Above the doorway WORKMEN are hanging a LARGE BANNER.  It

dialogues.text: The school children burst into a three story space domina life-sized statue of a HERD OF ELEPHANTS.  The kids chatt excitement, look up in awe.  Margo nods to a GUARD who sm pins on a plastic I.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Dr. Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Joe.  Beautiful day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry watches Margo pass through the turnstiles without p swaggers over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans down, amused) I'm an Evolutionary Biologist.  What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  I'm in third grade.  What's a revolutionary what ch'a ma' callit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evolutionary Biologist.  I study how life on earth evolved over millions of years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightens) Way cool.  Then you know where the dinosaurs are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourth floor, West wing, but stay with your class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Beasley heads into the museum and Larry and Henry me rest of the kids.  Margo turns towards the stairwell, pas IAN CUTHBERT... Museum Director... a pudgy man in wire ri dresses and thinks like a banker.  Hired for his amazing raise money, Cuthbert is one of a new generation of Museu whose focus must always be on the bottom line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Ian.  Everything ready for the opening of the Superstition Exhibit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on my way to get the last piece out of storage right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd wish you luck but I'm not superstitious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be after tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert waves merrily.  A workman uses a LADDER in the s Cuthbert is about to walk under the ladder, stops and car around it instead.  Margo smiles, goes on upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert enters from the lower stairwell.  He is now in o hundreds of areas of the museum that are closed to the th public.  He follows a labyrinthine route down a dim passa with rumbling steam pipes.  There are storage areas on bo labeled ORNITHOLOGY, HERPITOLOGY, CENTRAL ASIA EXPEDITION EXPEDITIONS, WHALE BONE FOSSILS and so on.  Finally Cuthb door marked "WHITTLESLEY EXPEDITIONS 1978-95".  Cuthbert pauses and g but to his surprise the door pushes open.  The lock and d mechanism are both broken off!  Cuthbert frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert flips on a light to see a tall, narrow space.  S shelves reach up into the gloom.  Everywhere we see spear masks, various artifacts.  Ancient tribal costumes lie sh plastic like corpses against the walls.  And in the middl gloom, sitting ominously in the light of a sole hanging b THE WHITTLESLEY CRATES.  The same ones last seen in the h ill-fated Santa Lucia.  They are scattered about in disar particular has been broken open, its contents spread on t Cuthbert mutters in surprise and dismay, kneels by the cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it can't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert feels gently through the packing material, lets relief as he pulls out a figurine.  It is a small, beauti statue of A MONSTER crouched on all fours. The room falls totally silent as Cuthbert studies THE REL truly frightening piece... massive, razor sharp claws, la nostrils, enormous teeth and red rimmed eyes.  Suddenly C DROP OF BLOOD on his hand!  He's been CUT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert rises, shakes his finger in pain.  Blood drips o He pulls out his pocket handkerchief and wraps the wound. handkerchief rapidly soaks through.  Suddenly a HAND CLAM Cuthbert's shoulder!  He's not alone!  He lets out a YELP dropping the Relic and spins to see...  A MUSEUM GUARD standing behind him.  His nameplate reads. He's a gentle young fellow with white blond hair and a ro southern accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beauregard!  You scared me half to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir.  You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone broke into this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything missin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't look like it.  We're damned lucky.  This statue is priceless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert holds up the RELIC of THE MONSTER.  Beauregard s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mbwun.  A South American warrior deity.  He carries a powerful curse. Every member of the expedition that found this statue, died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beauregard sees Cuthbert's cut finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like the curse is still at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The claws are sharp... I must have cut myself. (uneasy laugh) Better move these crates to the secure storage area where they'll be safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beauregard studies the door as Cuthbert heads out with th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know if it'll do any good, Mr. Cuthbert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one broke into this room, sir. Someone broke out.  That lock was torn off from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert glances at the evil face of Mbwun, pales.  As he ON BEAUREGARD, left alone with the crates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge centrifuges, hissing autoclaves, electrophoresis app glowing monitors, elaborate blown-glass distillation colu titration set-ups.  One of the most advanced technical fa its kind.  And mixed in with all the modern machinery are SKELETONS OF ALL KINDS.  Complete homo sapien specimens a around the room.  Standing midst all this is GREGORY KAWA twenties.  Kawakita makes sharp, jerky overhead movements hand, waving something about.  He's practicing casting. zing of a line and the whirring of the fly reel as MARGO whips out, passing right under her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third from the end!  Right shoulder. Aleut, provenance unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fly zooms across the room and lights on the shoulder skeleton from the end, labeled "Aleut, provenance unknown rolls her eyes and Kawakita smiles with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I spent half the time on my Fractal Evolution thesis that I spend on this fly rod, I'd have my PhD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (small smile) But at what a price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kawakita reels in his line as Margo drops her backpack on desk.  An enormous MICROSCOPE stands by the equally impos topped by a tiger skull.  A screen saver of an animated p plays.  Margo unpacks boxes of fossil teeth, hits some ke columns of seemingly indecipherable chemical equations on screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the species identification on these teeth.  We can extract DNA and start running tests on the extrapolator program.  Call Dr. Frock.  He wanted a demonstration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo, you haven't heard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frock's been fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo straightens, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkward) I'm sorry to be the bearer of bad tidings, but you know me.  Telegraph. Telephone.  Tell Kawakita.  I got the definitive word from Cuthbert's secretary.  This is Dr. Frock's last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo is already out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo charges through double doors leading into the south She half runs down an elegant, Edwardian fifth-floor corr footsteps lost in the thick carpet.  At the very end is a door bearing a plate entwined with bronze leaves that rea "Dr. Frock".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo bursts into the unique office, which is in startlin the modernity of her own.  Two large bow windows look out park.  Upholstered Victorian chairs in a leaf motif sit o carpets featuring large red roses.  Plant specimens and d flora and fauna line the walls.  Cardboard boxes cover th Seated in a wheelchair is a white-haired man in a tweed j loud floral tie.  Glasses slip down his nose. This is DR. FROCK, and he's in the middle of packing.  He smiles apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Margo.  Sorry about the mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true?  Greg said you'd been fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Bit of a shock.  But as Cuthbert so tactfully put it, the museum needs new blood.  And since I've been here since the Mesozoic Era --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Margo, don't overreact.  Cuthbert has to cut costs somehow.  My leaving makes perfect sense.  This isn't exactly early retirement.  I've overstayed the party a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't do without you.  You're one of the foremost authorities on primitive pharmacology.  You're practically an institution around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, apparently, is the problem. I'm yesterday's news.  Who needs a Curator of Plant Biology in a museum with one exhibit on plants?  Monsters and dinosaurs, cannibals and shamans are the new currency of the realm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frock goes back to his work packing to hide his emotion a moves to his side.  She pulls Frock's books back out of t returns them to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Phyletic Transformation and the Tertiary Fern Spike" is not going anywhere.  I'll talk to Cuthbert and put a stop to this right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts for the door and Frock wheels into her path. first time she sees what he's been carefully hiding... th his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.  Don't humiliate me further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help.  I can take care of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Margo.  This is one problem you can't solve.  You have to stay out of it.  The fact is, I want to retire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you say that?  You know it's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is.  I'm tired and I'm no longer needed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My work on fossil intermediates would be crippled without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, dear, that's bull.  You dance rings around me with your new technology.  You've left me in the dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stubbornly loyal) Your work is highly relevant.  What about your display on Primitive Pharmacology?  Cuthbert told me himself he was going to feature it prominently in the Superstition Exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healing plant use among the Ki tribe of Bechuanaland has been cancelled to make room for Tibetan Erotic Art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frock reaches out and squeezes her hand gently with a loo the discussion is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.  I'll walk you back to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not giving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frock rolls back down the hall the way Margo just came. beside him, downcast.  She's not used to defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a death sentence.  Greg has promised to teach me fly fishing.  I'll garden.  I'll write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are this museum.  It won't be the same without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone needs a change of scenery. I've been rolling down these halls for forty-odd years.  That's quite enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo gets in the elevator reluctantly.  He smiles and me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you at lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves her off merrily.  But once the doors close and M sight, Frock's smile fades and his shoulders sag.  He duc wheelchair quickly into the Hall of African Mammals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two stories high, dark and dramatic.  A very special disp of lions, hippos, wart hogs etc.  In the middle is a larg GORILLA beating its chest.  Frock takes refuge in the dar exhibit.  His wheelchair sits in a quiet corner and we se wipe the back of his hands across his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shells and sea life line the walls.  A sign announces the "Mollusks and Our World."  The THIRD GRADE CLASS sweeps i Henry start to sing "Mollusks and Our World" to the tune to Our World", the F.A.O. Schwartz theme song.  Mrs. Beas them the evil eye and Henry whines...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Beasley, it's almost time to go and we still haven't seen the dinosaurs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ask me about the dinosaurs once more, I'II strangle you both!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to lecture about horseshoe crabs in a droning Henry and Larry hang back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) This room sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's never going to take us to see the dinosaurs.  That lady said they were on the fourth floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's ditch and find them ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dart off down a side corridor and up a wide stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Henry emerge and walk wide-eyed among the cases chameleons, tortoises.  High windows light the room.  Out going down.  A woman pushing a child in a stroller exits have the hall to themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this.  A Komodo dragon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Larry checks out, the huge, dragon-like reptile, which sunk its Jaws into a stuffed boar.  Henry points to a stu climbing vertically up the side of its case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check out this one.  It can walk up walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry already has his eyes on the far end of the hall whe barricades have been put up to prevent access to the next Painting is in progress.  Scaffolding just begs to be cli runs over and starts up the scaffolding.  Larry hesitates

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not supposed to go back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicken.  This is a great short cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry drops on the other side of the scaffolding and Larr a moment both disappear from sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Windowless and dark.  A closed display under maintenance. little stuffed birds line the walls from floor to ceiling cotton poking out of sightless eyes.  Henry and Larry ent down.  Larry's getting scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a wuss.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys continue onward more slowly, their footfalls ech silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are now far from the other tourists and thei Larry is frightened.  The hall takes a sharp dog-leg, end darkened cul-de-sac full of display cases filled with hid masks.  Against the side of the chamber is a barricade of looks much like a wall.  Henry tugs at it and the barrica looks behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, there's a secret staircase back here.  Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry disappears behind the barricade leaving Larry compl in the dark room with the Shaman masks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, come back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry doesn't respond.  The lights in the cases throw str Larry starts to sniffle, falls to hiccuping, sits down. little flap of rubber that's coming off the toe of his sn bravado gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry!  Henry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.  Larry rises and peeks behind the barricade. circular stair.  It descends into total darkness.  From b strange smell that makes Larry's nose wrinkle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.  Larry puts his first foot on the stair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry!  Come up!  Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With no other option but staying alone in the dark, Larry Henry down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry clutches the banister, whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry?  Where are you?  Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry takes another step.  Another.  And another.  He sto hears SNUFFLING, rather like a large dog.  Larry freezes, cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry!  Henry!  It smells awful. Answer me!  Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry can barely see a dim hallway stretching out in two He pauses near the bottom of the stairs, eyes wide, holdi breath.  There appears to be a darker area of SHADOW at t hall.  It's gliding TOWARDS THEM! Suddenly something CLOSES on Larry's leg and he YELPS.  I Henry pulls Larry the rest of the way down the stairs.  T alone together in the darkness.  Henry hisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  But I think it's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep their eyes locked on the shape at the end of th they back up, step by step.  Move in as their faces sudde FEAR.  THE BOYS... SCREAM BLOODY MURDER... The sound echo darkness as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo sits up in the darkness, gasping.  Moonlight cuts a It takes a moment for her to realize that she's had a nig reaches for her light.  As she switches it on, we see a p bedside table.  It shows a group on a mountain in TIBET. several people with their arms slung around each other. a younger MARGO holding hands with JOHN WHITTLESLEY.  The more than friends. ON MARGO... she looks at the photo a moment, then turns o and lies back, alone in her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow crime tape encircles the museum.  Dead leaves swir and the sky is overcast.  Overnight, fall turned to winte of the museum is ringed with police cars.  Margo rides up and pauses, startled at the sight.  We watch as she cross words with one of the officers who motions her to a side wheels her bike under a stone tunnel as we pick up...  A TAXI CAB arriving at the front entrance.  Out steps SPE PENDERGAST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo enters.  The huge hall is taken up by an enormous b from the trunk of a single tree.  Inside it are mannequin Coast Indians.  Milling around are at least twenty COPS. approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worried, Margo hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All employees are to go to the IMAX room for a briefing, Dr. Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several cops go by with tracking dogs.  Margo looks back increasingly uneasy, almost bumps into...  HENRY AND LARRY.  Surprisingly, they are alive and well a MRS. BEASLEY outside an office.  Margo exchanges a look w remembering them from yesterday.  A tentative smile start and Larry don't return it.  Serious and chastened, they d eyes.  Margo continues on. TWO COPS stand outside the door to the rest room, their b to Margo as she approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?  Six?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo glances past them to see an OLDER MAN wearing the b NIGHT WATCHMAN, leaning over a sink.  He wipes his mouth. move down to see... THE MAN'S SNEAKERS are soaked in bloo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More cops gather, surrounded by skeletons of primates... monkeys, gorillas.  It's an odd sight.  They all look up as in walks the imposing figure of...  SPECIAL AGENT PENDERGAST.  He turns to a young eager beav BAILEY, flashes his badge.  Bailey straightens to attenti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you please take me to the officer in charge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast follows Bailey as they descend the rickety old staircase that goes into the bowels of the museum.  The h is narrowand lit by an occasional bare bulb.  The stairwa maze-like set of rooms in the basement.  Everything aroun STREAKED and SPATTERED in BLOOD.  There are trails of it the walls, the overhead light. Several COPS stand guard as DETECTIVE VINCE D'AGOSTA goes area.  He is a round, balding, man with an unmistakable a authority.  A modern knight in shining armor in disguise. disguise.  He has on a cheap polyester short sleeved shir is plainly visible underneath.  On his worn plastic belt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch anything until the S.O.C.  has finished with those stairs.  Keep everyone clear of the perimeter.  I don't want any contamination.  There's an incredible amount of blood evidence down here. We need more light.  Where's the photographer?  Tell him to quit eating donuts, I need him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pendergast enters, D'Agosta looks up at this serious A American in simple black suit, white shirt and dark tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?  The undertaker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Special Agent Pendergast.  FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince D'Agosta.  Am I out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.  I think we may be working on the same case.  If so, I could use your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men shake hands.  They couldn't be more different is an elegant intellectual... D'Agosta a working class sp operates from the gut.  Pendergast gestures to the form o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's left of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I have a look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'Agosta calls to A POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER who comes down th carrying lights, a donut stuffed in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need light in here, stat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'Agosta points to a lump the size of a bowling ball that corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful.  That mess on the ground is brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose footprints?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night watchman who found the body. Sweet old man.  Been tossing his cookies for over an hour.  Not a likely suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographer is finally ready and he floods the dark light.  And now everyone (but not us) gets a very clear l body. THE PHOTOGRAPHER... spits out his donut.  His eyes roll u in a dead faint.  Just like that.  D'Agosta swallows hard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast looks down, utterly impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'd say we're definitely working on the same case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old 19th century theater.  Balconies.  Heavy curtains. the theater where Lincoln was shot, with the exception of recent addition, an IMAX SCREEN five stories high.  The r with museum employees, all murmuring anxiously.  Margo si to Frock's wheelchair.  Her face is ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Frock, I just saw a man back there who'd been wading in blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Greg Kawakita sits in the chair next to Margo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For once I'm glad you're rumor central.  What in the world is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's been murdered.  Not shot, strangled or stabbed, either.  Torn limb from limb.  There's talk of a psychotic killer or even an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For heaven's sake, Greg, someone's been killed.  Look, it's Cuthbert. Let's hear what really happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this everyone falls silent and IAN CUTHBERT steps forw address the crowd.  He appears drawn and grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has been a tragic and upsetting morning.  I have terrible news for us all.  A member of our security force has been found murdered.  The police have just informed me it was Daniel Beauregard. (murmuring fills the room) Quiet.  Please.  With the help of our head of security, Mr. Ippolito... the museum has been secured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IPPOLITO... rises in the back and nods to the crowd... He looking, pompous man with shifty eyes.  Right now he's de Overnight, his job is on the line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police are satisfied we're in no danger, that we're all perfectly safe.  We've been asked to remain in the Gem Room and be available for questioning for the rest of the day. Obviously, we will all do everything we can to cooperate.  Are there any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ippolito raises a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party for the opening of the Superstition Exhibit... I imagine in the light of what's happened it will be pushed back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No action has been taken yet.  The opening of the exhibit is crucial to the financial health of this museum. So for now, we expect that the Superstition Exhibit will open on schedule, tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ippolito registers surprise.  The audience buzzes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo, Dr. Frock and Greg Kawakita enter.  The room is fu spectacular displays of gemstones of every type.  Greg dr over a grey sofa.  Margo leans on a giant geode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Cuthbert.  What a piece of work. Someone's dead and all he cares about is his Superstition Exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert's counting on the exhibition's success.  The museum is in debt.  Contributions and public funding have dried up.  Admissions no longer cover overhead.  The last big infusion of cash we had was the King Tut exhibit.  Cuthbert was hired to get us out of the red.  If the Superstition Exhibit isn't lucrative, he'll have to start auctioning off some of these gems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all this bad publicity, it's no wonder he looks like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They glance over and see Cuthbert in the corner.  He appe compulsively fingering his watch chain from which hangs a FOOT.  Frock goes over to speak to him, followed by Margo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ian.  Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Beauregard.  I can't believe it.  I may have been the last one to see him alive.  He was with me just yesterday, when I got out the statue of Mbwun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Mbwun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sensing more gossip) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo frowns, suddenly uneasy.  She and Dr. Frock exchang

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warrior deity of the Kothoga, an extinct South American tribe.  Dr. John Whittlesley led an expedition that found the only known representation of Mbwun.  The statue is said to carry a curse. (she looks away, quiet) Every member of Whittlesley's expedition died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the relic out yesterday to put on display.  Beauregard was there. The crates had been broken into and the contents were strewn about.  But nothing was missing.  It was downright weird.  We joked that it was the curse of Mbwun.  I'm not laughing now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Ian.  We all know you're superstitious.  But you're among scientists here.  We deal in facts. That statue had nothing to do with what happened to Beauregard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is, everyone who has come in contact with that relic, is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'Agosta has set up a temporary command post among the an and chairs.  The room is on the ground floor with a view Gawkers are outside looking in.  D'Agosta pulls the blind faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters) Get a life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast is looking closely at one of the large paintin that line the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An original Roger Tory Peterson of a Red-Breasted Merganser.  Amazing.  I have a copy of this in my office at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't really focus on birds at the moment, Pendergast.  I'm tryin' to keep my breakfast down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this violent world, I believe the only way to stay sane is to take time to notice beautiful things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drink.  After hours of course.  On duty, I smoke. (he pulls out a fat cigar) Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.  I enjoy the smell of a good cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you won't like this one.  It's a piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bites off the end, spits it out on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Vince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you read about a boat that washed up outside of New Orleans about four months ago?  Twelve bodies on board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who didn't?  Big news.  Out of Brazil, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  That's my case.  Now it's yours. All the corpses were badly mutilated in a very particular way. Decapitated.  Brains extracted.  Limbs torn to shreds.  It looked like the work of a large animal, but there was no sign of an animal on board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the method of death is the only connection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  There's more.  There were crates from this museum in the hold of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAILEY enters, interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Vince.  Sorry.  This won't wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a couple of kids who were lost yesterday near the site of the murder.  Claimed they saw a monster. They're pretty determined to tell you their story.  You want to see them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolls his eyes) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind, this could be important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modern classroom that has been taken over by the police purpose of interrogation.  Seated on small chairs at a pl are...  HENRY and LARRY, looking like two little boys with a stor desperate to share.  Standing behind them is MRS. BEASLEY than ever.  D'Agosta takes a chair across from the boys, level.  By this time of day he looks pretty rumpled and t Pendergast stands upright and unruffled in a doorway behi isn't hard duty for D'Agosta.  He's surprisingly genial a with kids.  Larry kicks his sneaker against the table leg excitement.  Henry tugs his t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  I'm Lieutenant D'Agosta.  You can call me Vince.  This is Special Agent Pendergast.  You can call him...  (he looks to Pendergast, so formal) Special Agent Pendergast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Henry Weiss and Larry Bowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... Tell us about this monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were lost and trying to find a short cut to the dino--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry elbows him hard.  Larry shuts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just lost, okay?  And we went down this curvy staircase.  At the bottom was a big shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big as a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well almost.  Depends which house.  It smelled like old hamburger, and it made this weird noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry makes a low GROWL in his throat.  D'Agosta suppress shoots Pendergast a look.  But Pendergast watches the kid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it snuffled the ground like a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes on hands and knees, sniffs the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It had a long tongue, teeth this big and yellow eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were green eyes and they were slit like a lizard's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were yellow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're color blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, please! (to D'Agosta) These two get in a lot of mischief and they tell some amazing whoppers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a whopper!  It's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast now moves forward, pulls up a chair as if deep interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ran and screamed and stuff.  And we got through a little door just in time.  There was a guard there and he went back to check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guard?  Do you remember his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was wearing one of those I.D. badges.  His name was Bo... something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beauregard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ambulance pulls away, lights flashing.  Pendergast and to a squad car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to admit, that was a damn sight better than "the dog ate my homework".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you explain the part about Beauregard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They heard the victim's name and wove him into their story.  Nice touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believed them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'Agosta stops, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think what we've got here is a monster as big as a house that smells... like hamburger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I think what we've got here is a psychotic killer wielding some kind of unusual weapon... who wants us to believe he's a monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (totally confused) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'Agosta and Pendergast thread their way down a hall line on gurneys.  It's dark and quiet.  They go into the autop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large gurney, currently empty, sits like an uninvited g the bright lights of the autopsy suite.  Beside it is a t doctor in her late 50's, with intense eyes.  This is DR. her are the PHOTOGRAPHER seen passing out at the museum, intern, DOCTOR GROSS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late, Vince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Dr. Ziewzic.  This is Special Agent Pendergast.  Pendergast, Dr. Ziewzic.  She runs the best chop shop in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've met.  The Hacksaw Murders.  '89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes!  Who could forget.  Afterwards you sent me that amazing case of Chateau Lafitte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you liked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely bouquet.  After our last case, Vince took me out for a draft beer. As I recall we split the check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumbles) It's been one of those days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she snaps her rubber glove) Shall we get down to it, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Gross wheels the gurney over to the morgue bank and s drawer.  The shape under the plastic seems too small to b the side of it is a large bump, presumably the head.  The cadaver are slid onto the gurney and wheeled under the li stainless steel bucket is placed under the gurney's outle Ziewzic fiddles with a microphone hanging above the body, and it gives off the proper static.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (for the microphone) This is Dr. Matilda Ziewzic, assisted by Dr. Frederick Gross. It's Oct. 28, six fifteen p.m.  We are joined by Lieutenant Vincent D'Agosta of the NYPD, Special Agent Pendergast of the FBI and a police photographer.  Let's see what we've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull off the sheet and D'AGOSTA swallows hard, close keep his stomach in check.  The photographer goes green, determined not to clutch this time.  PENDERGAST leans clo impassive.  He puts on a small pair of wire rim glasses, expression much like a man reading a menu in a restaurant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caucasian male.  Age about 27.  Blond. Height well I can't give a height because Mr. Beauregard has been decapitated.  The state of the body is such that other identifying marks are out of the question.  There are numerous lacerations proceeding from the left anterior pectoral downwards through the sternum and terminating in the abdomen.  This is a massive wound, two feet long and a foot wide.  The head has suffered severe trauma and the occipital portion of the calavarium has been crushed and removed.  It almost looks like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) A bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ziewzic turns to Pendergast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we talking about here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone who makes the Hacksaw Murderer look like Mother Teresa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. (back to work) The entire brain appears to have been extracted.  May I see it, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gross passes over a grey, watery mass that sits in a stai pan.  Ziewzic studies Beauregard's brain, or what's left

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curious.  There's something missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thalamus and the hypothalamus, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up, surprised) Yes.  Two organs the size of a walnut have been removed with what looks like surgical precision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind a suggestion, you might try a saliva test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ziewzic, Gross and D'Agosta look at Pendergast.  The phot staring at the wall, silently mouthing multiplication tab from woofing all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Saliva test?  You mean, you think someone ate part of the brain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long moment of silence, then... Zwiezic uses a swab for test, puts the result in a petrie dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  One saliva test.  Now... let's look at these lacerations.  They start wide and then converge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long fingernails?  Scratches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too extreme.  Perhaps some kind of weapon.  I'm now probing the wound and... there's a piece of foreign material deep in the muscle, lodged on a rib.  Photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographer gathers his courage, steps forward with Pendergast.  Zwiezic rinses the object off in a beaker of water.  It turns brownish red.  She holds it up.  They al astonished silence.  D'Agosta swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a claw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographer's flash goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black and white heads uptown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast sits in silence.  D'Agosta is visibly disturbe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like animals.  Never have. Dog bit me when I was little.  After that I gave up on pets.  Animals are irrational.  Give me a psychotic killer any day.  If there's one thing that makes me queasy it's being part of a food chain.  My first case as a rookie, two brothers climbed a fence at the zoo.  It was late August.  Over ninety.  The polar bear was inside his cave.  Kids didn't know he was in there.  All they saw was the pool. They got to swimming and splashing. The noise woke up the bear.  By the time I arrived, both little boys were in pieces.  The bear was dragging one kid around by the foot. I can still hear the mother screaming --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't an animal, Vince.  I've been on this case four months, remember?  I've learned a few things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been holding out on me Pendergast.  You have a suspect capable of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast looks over, nods quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you about it, Vince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The yellow crime scene tape is torn and flapping in a lig of the emergency vehicles have left.  The police have rel employees who are now headed home.  We see Frock and Kawa Cuthbert isn't far behind.  Pendergast approaches them, h inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.  Has Dr. Green left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before eight?  You must be joking. She's in the physical anthro lab making up for lost time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast nods his thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gems glow in the darkness as Pendergast passes throug empty room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast's footfalls are lost in the carpet as he goes stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast goes down a long, dark hall alone.  He arrives marked PHYSICAL ANTHROPOLOGY LAB, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skeletons throw odd shadows on the ceiling.  Margo's screen glows at the end of the room, casting the only lig chair is empty.  The room is quiet.  Pendergast approache around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Green?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.  Pendergast glances at the computer screen, se complicated notations.  He scrolls down, leans closer.  H it out.  He slides into Margo's chair, fascinated.  Then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a warrant to look at that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast leaps up.  Margo has appeared in the doorway b cup of coffee in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Special Agent Pendergast.  FBI. Forgive me.  I guess I was snooping. What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An invention of mine.  It's a computer program designed to describe the characteristics of a given species from a reading of its DNA.  I call it the Genetic Sequence Extrapolator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a DNA analysis from a fossil you can use this program to tell the species and sex of the animal, whether it was nocturnal, what it ate, how it hunted, how big it was...  (abrupt) You aren't here for a lesson in DNA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (a moment) I came to talk about Dr. John Whittlesley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo turns to put down her coffee.  She takes a moment t herself.  When she turns back, her voice is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow, when all this happened... I knew it would come back to John.  Is he really dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he were alive he'd have contacted me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have time to talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast and Margo walk together though various exhibit They pass dioramas of ferocious wild animals that have be stuffed behind glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Whittlesley was last seen in Belem, Venezuela a week after the rest of his expedition disappeared. A taxi driver drove him to the harbor where he boarded a cargo boat.  That boat washed up in my district.  Everyone on board was killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappeared.  His body wasn't among the victims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people killed were mauled and their brains were eaten.  Just like Beauregard.  One part of the brain was extracted with surgical precision.  The hypothalamus and thalamus to be exact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo pales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John couldn't have anything to do with a horrible thing like that.  He was a fine man despite his problems --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You loved him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a moment, taken aback) Yes.  Once.  We met at Columbia.  John held the Cadwalader Chair in Statistical Paleontology when I was a grad student there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were going to be married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ran an internet search on Dr. Whittlesley.  Got a list of his scholarly articles and the engagement announcement in the Times.  I also found a record of your restraining order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was two years ago.  John was still in love with me. (she looks down) He wouldn't leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were afraid of him, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was afraid of himself.  He tried suicide once.  He was ill.  Manic depressive.  He had wild emotional highs and lows.  Not a happy affliction for a scientist.  He'd been revered in our community.  By the end he was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about the last expedition. What was he looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A legendary monster called Mbwun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A monster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  He developed his own theory that he called the Calisto Effect. It held that evolution wasn't always gradual or driven by natural selection.  The environment would sometimes cause sudden and grotesque changes which could result in a "monster species".  It made no sense. But he felt he had evidence that Mbwun was such a monster, living in isolation on the tepui for thousands of years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one knows.  The Kothoga who live on the tepui are cannibals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo's voice catches again.  Pendergast reaches for his but she shakes her head, determined to keep control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm all right.  I won't let this affect me anymore.  John wouldn't get help.  His ego endangered the lives of others.  His theory came first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if Whittlesley arrived on the tepui and no monster was there?  Was he desperate enough to create one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something came up in autopsy tonight.  Imbedded in Beauregard's body we found a claw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God.  Then it was an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.  I think we were meant to think it was Mbwun.  Did Whittlesley's monster have claws?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  He sent back a statue that's supposed to be an exact representation.  But I've never seen it.  It's in the exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind showing it to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This exhibit is unlike anything we've seen in the museum. artifacts under single spots appear to float in a velvet Patterns of light and shadow play over skeletons and vood There are tombs, a torture chamber, and endlessly curving winding halls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would we find it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.  We should split up. You take that hall and I'll take this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  I'm as macho as you are. Perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without further discussion, Margo takes the right fork le Pendergast behind.

dialogues.speaker: ON MARGO...
dialogues.text: As she finds herself alone.  The silence is intense.  She into another long, dark, tunnel passing a set of Maori ta The eyes are stuffed with fibers, the shriveled lips are from rotting teeth.  Margo passes without a look.

dialogues.speaker: ON PENDERGAST
dialogues.text: In another part of the exhibit, he nears a Mayan tomb.  A the center wears a headdress and tribal robes.  Gold ring bony fingers.  Pendergast takes a moment to appreciate it the next hall.

dialogues.speaker: ON MARGO
dialogues.text: getting farther from pendergast, and ever deeper into the walls around her are lined with symbols of witchcraft.  T shaman dancers, masks covered in grasses and shells.  Fro Guinea coast there is Kokpah, God of a secret male societ ba, an awesome mannequin in black costume with an angry p Finally the walls open up into another gallery.  Beyond i the shadowy hall.  Margo stops and for the first time she gallery is the most frightening yet.  It features images from different cultures around the world. In the dim light, Margo is dwarfed by abhorrent statues o TORNARSUK (the Eskimo evil spirit), INCUBI from India, Ti Guinea etc.  And there in the center of the gallery sitti and lit by a spot, is a small figurine.  Margo is instant it.  As she gets close enough she sees the label in Gothi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Savage God of the Kothoga, also known as "HE WHO WALKS ON ALL FOURS".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The statue is terrifyingly life-like.  Margo stares at Th is covered in scales and stiff hair, with glittering gree crude, reptilian features.  The figure is hunched over in crouch.  It's long forearms trail to the ground ending in

dialogues.speaker: CLAWS
dialogues.text: ON MARGO... she starts, then remembers Pendergast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pendergast!  I found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.  She turns, tries again, louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast!  Over here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voice catches as she stops and sniffs the air.  A STE her.  She covers her face, backs up, holding her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps directly into a nasty statue of the Tibetan lor Dead.  Margo starts, steadies the statue.  The room is si But then, unmistakably... she hears it.  An odd rustling Deliberate.  Maddeningly soft on the thick carpet.  And a THE SMELL.  Margo looks in the direction she came, down t hall.  Her voice comes out a bit frightened as she calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast? (no answer) Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now she freezes.  At last she's truly scared.  A shad against black, is gliding stealthily towards her, moving display cases and grinning artifacts! Margo stands stock still, her eyes on the shadow.  She le gasp of shock.  She can't believe her eyes.  It defies re she backs up.  She slips quietly through the exhibit and side.  In the next room she pauses again, listens... now distinctly animal, SNUFFLING SOUND! Something large is TRACKING HER!  There's no doubt. Overcome by a blind panic, Margo turns and runs.  She pas display on mythical creatures, disappears down another wi hall. Behind her comes...  THE POUNDING OF SOMETHING IN A HEAVY, LOPING RUN!  Whatev charging after her!  She turns another corner.  And anoth fast as she can!  But now the walls up ahead are narrowin ... a DEAD END! Margo slams up against a locked door with a window of gla features displays of terrifying totem poles.  All around carved faces seem to leap out!  She pounds on the door bu useless.  She's trapped.  And the thing is coming behind around the last bend when it stops!  Silence again envelo afraid to turn.  She can hear HEAVY BREATHING, and someth growl!  Reflected in the glass of the door in front of he dark hall.  Margo starts as a face appears IN THE REFLECT The image is wavering and unclear.  It's a large, hulking her!  TWO GLOWING SLIT GREEN EYES in the dark!  Margo SCR thing leaps forward, hitting one of the totem poles.  Mar the ground, unconscious.  At last we hear Pendergast call darkness falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Green!  Dr. Green!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON MARGO... lying on the carpet.  There's a large, nasty forehead.  The totem pole is on the floor beside her.  Le is PENDERGAST.  Margo starts to sit up.  Pendergast gentl her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you calling and I ran after you, but you kept disappearing and I couldn't keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she touches her forehead) You were behind me?  Running after me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast nods.  As Margo rises he tries to help her but off, collecting her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, I'm all right.  I remember now... It was an animal.  Something large!  I could smell it.  It was hunting me.  I saw two green eyes in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind me.  Over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo turns and points behind her to...  A large NORTHWEST COAST INDIAN MASK.  It's carved out of horrible grimace, inset with two glowing green eyes.  Pen it too, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  If you're positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans against the wall, touches her forehead, panic o again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't think straight at the moment.  I know how crazy this seems. Please, Mr. Pendergast, I need some fresh air.  Could you get me out of here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE COPS including MCNITT, RODRIGUEZ and ROGERS prepare exhibit.  All are armed.  Margo watches as Pendergast giv instruction.  She appears rattled and confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay in formation together.  Take it room by room.  Check for footprints, any signs of disturbance.  If you see or hear anything the least bit suspicious, I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to DOYLE, an older red-haired cop who takes up outside the exhibit.  Pendergast hands Doyle his walkie t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailey's going to be in the guard house outside.  Officer Van Dorn is right down that hall.  When McNitt's done, he'll relieve you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle nods.  Pendergast and Margo walk out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo and Pendergast exit.  The cold air is like a slap i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Green...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't imagine it.  I know what I saw.  Are you sure there are enough men in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all heavily armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops) All right.  This is hard for me.  I'm a scientist.  I like order and logic. Sometimes too much.  There's got to be an explanation.  There can't be an animal in there.  But I saw something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (she has a thought) Mr. Pendergast.  Do me a favor.  Get me a DNA readout on that claw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors to the exhibit are closed.  Doyle looks at his impatient.  It's almost eleven now.  He pulls out his wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailey?  Doyle here.  I'm still waiting outside the exhibit.  Where the hell is McNitt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should be there any minute.  They came out a side door a while ago. Said the exhibit's clear.  McNitt's headed back to spell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on double over-time, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  You can go home if you want to.  I'll come relieve you myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle shuts off his walkie talkie, frowns.  He fidgets, l watch once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, takes off the walkie talkie and leaves it, but something, stops.  It's a low SCUFFLING from inside the e from behind the closed doors.  Doyle freezes, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNitt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.  Doyle pauses.  His hand goes to his gun for r he hears a footstep and a muffled thump.  He moves to the exhibit, opens it and takes a step inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNitt?  Cut the crap.  I know it's you.  You're not scaring me.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence meets him.  The shadows of the exhibit loom.  Doy more step inside, scanning the darkness with his gun.  Do BREATHING?  He freezes.  Yes, he does.  The hair on his n loses the spit in his mouth.  He takes a step backwards, a second too late.  The door SLAMS BEHIND HIM and a HUGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer MCNITT enters from a side corridor, zipping up hi hall is still.  McNitt checks his watch, sees Doyle's wal turns it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNitt here.  I'm outside the exhibit.  All's quiet.  But I don't see Doyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He called a minute ago looking for you.  He starts vacation tomorrow and he wanted out.  I said you were on the way.  He could split.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any sign of a green-eyed monster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNitt shuts off the walkie talkie, settles at his post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the blackness a large shape is MOVING QUIETLY, draggin across the floor.  We move in on the lifeless form of DOY is rigid with terror, his eyes frozen, open wide.  The la hear as the hulking form heads back into the darkness, is of Doyle's skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signs announce that the Superstition Exhibit opens tonigh is back in business, but not many people are going in.  A at the margins, pointing at the building.  Several hold a POST with a graphic photo of the bloody floor by the circ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert stands by the window of his palatial office, loo the scene below.  His face is pinched with worry.  Slumpe Lieutenant D'Agosta.  Pendergast surveys some paintings o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea the Museum had a complete collection of Piranesi's Forum sketches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like them, they're for sale. Another day like yesterday and half the collection will be on the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've read about the Museum's financial troubles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been operating in the red for years.  That was the whole idea behind the Superstition Exhibit.  It was designed to pull people in. We've spent every penny we have on advance publicity, betting everything on the opening's success. If we postpone at the last minute...  No.  I don't want to think about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chews on his toothpick, mild) We all love the museum.  I come here myself with my kids.  We're trying to work with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the party goes forward, and that's a big if... I've arranged for a large police presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they have to wear uniforms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to scare people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.  But Mr. Cuthbert, we've got bigger problems.  Depending on what we find today, we may have to shut you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuthbert looks grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'Agosta examines the huge centrifuges, autoclaves, elect apparati, monitors, computers etc.  as Margo and Greg Kaw the claw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you make of it, Margo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not mammalian, that's for sure. I think it's reptilian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would jive with what we got from the preliminary DNA read-out. Here, have a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands them a computer read-out.  Margo checks it quick looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to this, twenty-five percent of the claw DNA is unidentifiable, about a third is homo sapien, and the rest is Hemidactylus Turcicus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks over) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo pulls off her glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turkish Gecko, I believe.  A lizard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lizard DNA and human DNA on the same strand?  Impossible.  The sample must be contaminated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another possibility.  A lot of repeated base pairs could suggest a high level of genetic damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genetic damage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When DNA is defective, it often uncontrollably replicates long repeating sequences of the same base pair.  Viruses can damage DNA.  So can radiation, certain chemicals.  Even cancer.  Let's let the G.S.E. sort it out.  I have to get started.  This will take several hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need someone to take us to the secure storage area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try Dr. Frock.  He's the curator of Plant Biology.  All the curators have keys.  And he knows every inch of this museum.  The rest of us still get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendergast, D'Agosta and Dr. Frock get off are in an olde corridor with a long row of locked heavy steel doors.  Th numbered up to eight, then the corridor turns. As the three go forward, the creaking of the wheelchair e in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for taking the time to help us with this, Dr. Frock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to be useful.  It's rare enough these days.  According to security, Beauregard put the Whittlesley crates in storage area 1012.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many storage areas are there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fill seven floors.  We have the largest collection of mammals and dinosaurs in the world.  Just to give you an idea, there are more than three million insects specimens.  Not to mention amphibians, reptiles, birds, anthropological artifacts, meteorites, minerals and gems.  Only about five percent of the museum collection is actually on display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place is a maze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm one of the few who know every inch it, now that John is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks over) Do you mean Dr. Whittlesley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  John made quite a study of the whole museum.  He had a copy of my original plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frock heads through a double door that leads to a FREIGHT that's as big as a small room.  The operator, KARL has it with a table, chair, and PICTURES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Osteo prep, Karl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors creak closed.  They are now inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headed down.  D'Agosta chews on a toothpick, stares at Ka picture show.  The photos have all been cut from nature m are of ANIMALS MATING in extreme positions and undreamed D'Agosta turns to Pendergast, dead pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My kind of art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl, who is sixty and wears a red toupee, leers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep me company.  Gets kinda lonely sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My favorite is the two camels.
